bibl.title: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to George E. Vincent, June 22, 1922

div1.p: Noguchi, referring to the 1921 Rockefeller Foundation report, attempts to clarify the claim that vaccinated soldiers did not contract yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to George E. Vincent, June 22, 1922
div1.p:
I have your letter of June 19th
enclosing copy of Dr. Carter's letter and your reply.

Soon after Dr. White returned from
his trip to Peru--it must have been in September or October,
1921, for he returned in August--he came to see me at the
Institute, told me that he felt assured of the efficacy of
the vaccine, and related the experience in Peru which Dr.
Carter questions. As Dr. White had just come from Peru,
I took the story to be authentic and have quoted it once
or twice. I think there can be no question of the fact,
though there seems to have been some misunderstanding about
who carried out the vaccinations. Perhaps they were done
by someone other than Dr. Hanson, or, if done by him, they
may have formed a part of the 200 vaccinations of soldiers
reported by him in his speech before the Medical Association
of the Canal Zone on August 19, as follows: “We vaccinated
about 1000 persons. In Lambayeque we vaccinated about 200
soldiers and had no cases among them, in spite of the fact
that they remained there before the fever had disappeared
from the place. In Paiján, which was the worst place, we had
no cases among 200 who had been vaccinated, and these people
were vaccinated very early in the game, when the fever was
still very severe. We do not know if they were immunes or
not. They gave us no assurance of having had the fever.”

I have forwarded the correspondence
to Dr. White in Mexico City, asking him to let me know as soon
as possible from whom he obtained the information regarding the
group of 50 soldiers, who carried out the vaccinations, and
where. I hope there has been no misunderstanding in such a matter as this.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, (Signed)Hideyo Noguchi President George E. Vincent
Rockefeller Foundation
61 Broadway, New York, N.Y.
